non_communicable_diseases.name: Cardiovascular Disease
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A range of diseases affecting the heart and blood vessels, including coronary artery disease, heart attack, and stroke.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: CVD often develops due to atherosclerosis, where plaque builds up in the arteries, narrowing them and restricting blood flow. Risk factors like high blood pressure and cholesterol contribute to this process.
prevention: Healthy diet (e.g., low in saturated fats and sugars)
Avoiding tobacco and excessive alcohol consumption
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image of the heart by Heart research Institute

non_communicable_diseases.name: Diabetes
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A chronic condition characterized by high levels of glucose in the blood due to insulin resistance or insufficient insulin production.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Diabetes occurs when the body either does not produce enough insulin (Type 1) or becomes resistant to insulin (Type 2), leading to elevated blood sugar levels.
prevention: Balanced diet rich in whole grains, fruits, and vegetables
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Diabetic device- image by Swansea University

non_communicable_diseases.name: Cancer
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A group of diseases characterized by uncontrolled cell growth and the potential to invade or spread to other parts of the body.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Cancer occurs when genetic mutations disrupt the normal cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled proliferation. Factors like tobacco use, radiation, and certain infections can increase risk.
prevention: Avoiding tobacco and limiting alcohol consumption
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Cancer cells - image by MD Anderson Cancer center

non_communicable_diseases.name: Chronic Respiratory Diseases
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A group of diseases affecting the airways and lungs, leading to difficulty in breathing and reduced lung function.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Chronic respiratory diseases like COPD result from long-term exposure to irritants that damage the lungs, such as tobacco smoke and air pollution.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image of a woman coughing - image by Visby Medical

non_communicable_diseases.name: Obesity
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A medical condition characterized by excess body fat that increases the risk of health problems.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Obesity occurs when energy intake from food exceeds energy expenditure, often due to a combination of genetic, environmental, and behavioral factors.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Over 650 million adults globally are obese
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image of an obese man - image by Brisbane Obesity Clinic

non_communicable_diseases.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A progressive loss of kidney function over time, which can lead to kidney failure and other complications.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Chronic kidney disease often develops due to long-term conditions such as diabetes and hypertension that damage the kidneys' filtering units.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Approximately 850 million people worldwide are affected
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image of a health worker holding a replica of a kidney - Image by National Kidney foundation

non_communicable_diseases.name: Alzheimer's Disease
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A progressive neurological disorder that causes brain cells to degenerate and die, leading to cognitive decline.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Alzheimer's occurs due to the buildup of proteins (amyloid plaques and tau tangles) in the brain, disrupting cell function and communication.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Over 50 million people worldwide are affected
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image of a young lady caring for an old lady

non_communicable_diseases.name: Hypertension
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A condition characterized by persistently high blood pressure in the arteries.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Hypertension can develop due to a combination of genetic factors, poor diet, lack of physical activity, and other health conditions that affect blood flow.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Approximately 1.13 billion people worldwide have hypertension
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image of a health worker assessing the blood pressure of a patient- Image by Northwest Houston Heart Center

non_communicable_diseases.name: Osteoporosis
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A condition characterized by weak and brittle bones, increasing the risk of fractures.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Osteoporosis occurs when the body loses too much bone mass or does not make enough bone, often influenced by hormonal changes, aging, and nutritional deficiencies.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Approximately 200 million people are affected globally
prevention: Adequate intake of calcium and vitamin D
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image illustrating pain as a result of Osteoporosis - image by Nitin Khanna MD

non_communicable_diseases.name: Mental Health Disorders
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A wide range of mental health conditions that affect mood, thinking, and behavior.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: These disorders can arise from a complex interplay of genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors, often triggered by stress or trauma.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Approximately 1 in 4 people will experience a mental health issue at some point in their lives
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Illustration of the mind - Image by Gosnells Women's Health service

non_communicable_diseases.name: Cirrhosis
non_communicable_diseases.definition: Severe scarring of the liver caused by liver disease, leading to impaired liver function.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Cirrhosis develops from long-term damage to the liver due to factors like chronic alcohol abuse, viral hepatitis, or fatty liver disease.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image illustration the liver inside the human body- Image by Bangalore Institute of Gastroenterology

non_communicable_diseases.name: Multiple Sclerosis
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A disease in which the immune system attacks the protective covering of nerves, leading to communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: MS is thought to be an autoimmune disorder where the immune system mistakenly attacks the myelin sheath surrounding nerve fibers, disrupting signal transmission.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image illustration of the brain and neural network. Image by NY neurology Associates

non_communicable_diseases.name: Parkinson's Disease
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A progressive neurological disorder that affects movement and can cause tremors and stiffness.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Parkinson's occurs due to the degeneration of dopamine-producing neurons in the brain, leading to a decrease in dopamine levels, which regulates movement.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image Illustration of a shaking hand - Image by Kobenhavns University

non_communicable_diseases.name: Gout
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A form of inflammatory arthritis characterized by sudden, severe attacks of pain, swelling, and redness in the joints.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Gout occurs when there is a buildup of uric acid in the blood, which can form crystals in the joints, leading to inflammation and pain.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Around 8.3 million people affected in the U.S.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Illustration of the gout on the joints of the toes

non_communicable_diseases.name: Asthma
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A chronic condition that affects the airways, causing wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Asthma occurs due to inflammation and narrowing of the airways, often triggered by allergens, irritants, and respiratory infections.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Picture of person using an inhaler

non_communicable_diseases.name: Fibromyalgia
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A chronic condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and sleep disturbances.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: The exact cause of fibromyalgia is unknown, but it is believed to involve a combination of genetic, environmental, and psychological factors that affect pain perception.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Approximately 4 million adults in the U.S. affected
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Picture of a person in pain

non_communicable_diseases.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve a combination of viral infections, immune dysfunction, and psychological stress.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Illustration of extreme fatigue

non_communicable_diseases.name: Skin Cancer
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A type of cancer that forms in the skin cells, often due to excessive sun exposure or tanning beds.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Skin cancer develops when UV radiation damages the DNA in skin cells, leading to uncontrolled growth and the formation of tumors.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: About 1 in 5 Americans will develop skin cancer by age 70
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image of the detection of skin cancer

non_communicable_diseases.name: Crohn's Disease
non_communicable_diseases.definition: An inflammatory bowel disease that causes inflammation of the digestive tract, leading to abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, and malnutrition.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: Crohn's disease occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks the gastrointestinal tract, causing inflammation. The exact cause is unknown but is thought to involve genetic and environmental factors.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Illustration of bowel disease

non_communicable_diseases.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A common disorder affecting the large intestine, characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, and changes in bowel habits.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: IBS is thought to be caused by abnormal muscle contractions in the intestine, sensitivity to certain foods, and stress, but the exact cause is not fully understood.
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image illustrating bowel dieases

non_communicable_diseases.name: Acid Reflux (GERD)
non_communicable_diseases.definition: A chronic digestive condition where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining.
non_communicable_diseases.how_it_occurs: GERD occurs when the lower esophageal sphincter fails to close properly, allowing stomach acid to flow back into the esophagus, causing symptoms like heartburn.
non_communicable_diseases.incidence: Approximately 20% of the U.S. population affected
non_communicable_diseases.image_alt: Image illustrating reflux disease
